utterance: Company, halt!

utterance: Well, Kate, here's the big prairie I told you of, and beyond that blue line of timber you see is Sun Prairie, and home.

utterance: Come here, Lincoln.

utterance: Here we are, out of sight of the works of man. Not a house in sight climb up here and see.

utterance: Attention, battalion! We must reach Sun Prairie to-night. Forward, march!
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Wake up, everybody. We're almost home.

utterance: All right.

utterance: Keep quiet. We're satis. fied as long as you don't arrest us. If you're going to arrest anybody, you've got to take us all.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Well, now I'll tell you, boys. Seein's you are all from the country, and seein's them ragamuffins set upon ye, I'll let ye go. But I can't have any more rowin' here. You better put out for home and get washed up. You look like you'd been run through a separator. Now, hyper.
speaker: the marshal of the day

utterance: I move we stay to the fireworks, and show 'em we're not afraid.

utterance: I'm going home.

utterance: So am I.

utterance: Sick, are you?

utterance: If you'd eat a little decent food and let truck' alone, you'd come home able to walk.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Let 'em alone, father. They know that as well as anybody. Now, for land sakes! what marked you all up like that? And look at your clothes! Well, you are in nice shape.

utterance: We licked 'em, anyway.

speaker: Mrs. Stewart

utterance: Well, now, Duncan, what do you 'spose the young 'uns have been into?
speaker: Mrs. Stewart

utterance: Send 'em to bed. We'll hear all about it in the morning.

utterance: Pack your middle hard, especially when you come to draw in. Tramp it down well, and you won't have any wet grain.

utterance: Well, Lincoln, I guess you are the boss stacker from this on.

utterance: I'm all right now,-go back to work.

utterance: You have still a half an hour, ladies and gentlemen, before the great show opens.

utterance: Still a half an hour to see the wonders of the world, Madame Ogoleda, the snake woman. Walk in—walk in; only a dime to see this wondrous woman and her monstrous serpent. The Bible story related. The woman and the snake. Only a dime apiece.
speaker: one

utterance: He is! He is! The fattest boy in the world. He weighs four hundred and eighty pounds. See him eat his dinner. Only a dime to see the fat boy eat a whole ham!
speaker: another

utterance: Professor Henry, court wizard of Beelzebub himself. Come in and see the great and marvellous man. You can see a glutton eat any day, but this is your only chance to see the magician of Mahomet. The Magi of the East! The King of Conjurors!

utterance: Clear the way there

utterance: What's up, Jim?

utterance: It's the Sheriff, you fool.

utterance: Sheriff, and the best man in the country, bar none.

utterance: This is a thimble-rigger. He's wanted in Cerro Gordo for robbery and he goes.
speaker: Jim Moriarty

utterance: You bet he goes. We know you, Jim. Go ahead.

utterance: And I want you, me friend, for interferrin' with an officer in the discharge of his duty. Open a path, b'ys.

utterance: Go before me, an' don't look back.
speaker: Jim Moriarty

utterance: If you weren't an officer and armed, you couldn't take me.
speaker: the angry man

utterance: My friend, ye're too ambitious. Ye're a foine bit of a b'y, but too soft to talk loike that to a workin' man.
speaker: Jim Moriarty

utterance: For a copper I'd show you.
speaker: the angry man

utterance: Has anny one a copper? I'm an accommodatin' man.
speaker: Jim Moriarty

utterance: What's all this? Are you the Sheriff? What's wanted? Let that man go!
speaker: the manager

utterance: Kape a civil tongue in yer head, an' shove out yer sharpers, or it'll go hard with ye to get out o' the county.
speaker: Jim Moriarty

utterance: This is a straight show. I want you to understand nothing goes crooked around me. I won't have my men interfered with. I won't have no gay sheriff jumpin'—
speaker: the manager

utterance: Listen! Open yer jaw at me agin, and I'll break yer silk hat, and stuff yer t'roat with the pieces.
speaker: Jim Moriarty

utterance: Lay a hand on our Sheriff, and, by jinks, we'll lynch every man o' ye.

utterance: Well, boys. That's all of it. Now we'll go and get some dinner.

utterance: There's our place, mother.

utterance: Away up there? Good land!

utterance: All a part of the show.

utterance: Where do we put our feet?

utterance: Anywhere you can get 'em.

utterance: They don't improve on their seats. It seems to me the seats used to be a good deal wider.

utterance: You were young then, Neighbor Jennings.

utterance: I guess that's the truth of it.

utterance: B'ys, ye can see better on yer seats. Go back; I'll attend to this small business. Go back, I say, and lave me to me work. This man is not a clown; he's a crook, and I need him to make a pair.

utterance: You're all right, Jim.

utterance:
I am.

to you, me beauty, I am not so sure you don't stand in with these crooks.

utterance: Tickets for the Minstrel Show only a quarter of a dollar. Let no one miss the songs and dances to follow. A grand entertainment will follow the final act!

utterance: Jim will take care of the man.

utterance: Hello, Lincoln !

utterance: Well, here I am.

utterance: Let's go to Clear Lake.

utterance: D'ye mean it ?

utterance: You bet. I can put in a horse. Bert Jenks will lend us his boat - put it right on in place of the wagon box - we can borrow Captain Knapp's tent.

utterance: I'm with you, But say, won't you go up and break it gently to the boss. He's got his mind kind o' set on goin' through this corn again. When'll we start?

utterance:
Let's see-to-day is Wednesday.

utterance: Well, now, if you don't mind, Milt, I'd like to have you go up and see what father says.

utterance: I'll fix him.

utterance: Where is he?

utterance: Right up the road, mending fence.

utterance: Well, now, don't set up too late, talkin' about gettin' off.
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

utterance: We're goin' to turn right in, ain't we, boys?
speaker: boys

utterance:
You bet.
We're goin' to get out of here before sun-up to-morrow mornin'.
speaker: Bert

utterance:
Well, see't you do, said to see boys have a good time.
But I guess I'll be up long before you are.
speaker: Mr. Jennings

utterance: Don't be too sure o' that.
speaker: boys

utterance: Now, the first feller that wakes up, yell.
speaker: Bert

utterance: First feller asleep, whistle.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: That won't be you, that's sure.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Say, boys, don't you think it's about time?
speaker: boys

utterance: Boys, it's gettin' daylight in the east!
speaker: boys

utterance:
No, it ain't.
That's the moon.
speaker: boys

utterance: Oh, wouldn't I like to jump into that water!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Well, this won't do. We must get a camp
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Where can a fellow camp?
speaker: Bert

utterance: Anywhere down in the woods.
speaker: a young man

utterance: Whoa!
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Now, who's goin' to catch the fish for breakfast?
speaker: Bert

utterance: I will, I'll have some fish by sun-up — see if I don't.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: I wish I could do this all the time.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I can tell better after a week of it.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Hello! that mosquito pretty near had you that time.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Look out there! You'll be tippin' over my butter!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Come on, boys, now for the boat.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: I guess not.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Hurrah! Whoop!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: That is all right. The question is, can we get back?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: You wait an' see me tack.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: All right. Tack or nail, only le's see you get back where we started from.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I'm going up to town with it after dinner.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: I'd sooner walk than ride in your boat.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: All right; you pays your money-you takes your choice.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Turn! turn it!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I'm afraid of breakin' my rudder.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Don't you see we can't get back?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Get on the edge!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: I don't suppose this is much of a blow, but I don't see any of the other boats out.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Luff, you lubber-why don't you luff?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Suppose you come help!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: I guess not! I'm only passenger. Hard-a-port, there, you'll have us playin' on the sand, yet. That's right. All we got to do is to hard-a-port when the wind blows.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Shut up, there, Link. Bail 'er out!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Don't you know any more'n to go out in such a tub as that on a day like this? I expected every minute to see you go over.
speaker: the boatkeeper

utterance: We didn't. I guess we made pretty good time.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Time! you'd better say time! If you'd been five minutes later, you'd had time enough.
speaker: the boatkeeper

utterance: By golly! We thought you were goners. Why, we couldn't see the boat, after you got out a little ways. Looked like you were both sittin' in the water.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: By golly! I wish I had one o' mother's biscuits this morning.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Land o' Goshen, you eat as if you were starved. What did you live on?
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

utterance: Fish.
speaker: Bert

utterance: Sour bread.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Well, no wonder you look gaunt as weasels.
speaker: Mrs. Jennings

utterance: Oh, but it was fun, wasn't it, boys?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: You bet it was. Let's go again next year.
speaker: boys

utterance: All right, raise your weapons and swear to be true to the 'poet.'
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Well, Lincoln, you've been aching to take your station for some years. Now you can show your mettle. I'll put you into the field this year as a full hand.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: All right. I'm ready for it.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Now, boys, it's going to be hot, and this being the first day, we'll take it tolerably slow and easy. I'd hate to have any of you 'peter out.'
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Oh, you needn't worry about us. If the boy goes through, I think we will.
speaker: Long John

utterance: You follow the boy, and you'll earn your wages, and don't you forget it.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: When I was sixteen I could rake and bind with any man I ever saw. I guess Lincoln'll look after himself.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: That 'jacknape' thinks he is going to bind us off our legs.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Well, if he does, he'll earn his board. I'd break my back rather than get caught to-day.
speaker: Ben Hutchison

utterance: Well, the boys didn't get caught, after all.
speaker: Ben Hutchison

utterance: No, I came mighty near it once. I run a stubble under my nail, and had to get it out.
speaker: Ben Hutchison

utterance: The tug of war will come about four o'clock to-day.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: But I reckon I'm good for it.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Why, it's play, standing up against you boys.
speaker: Long John

utterance: You never mind me, father. Take the conceit out of that chap, or we can't live with him.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: How're you standing it, Lincoln ?
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Oh, I'm all right. Don't worry about me. How's Ben?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: He's about 'bushed,' but I guess he'll hold out till supper.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: All right, we'll make that Jack-knife think he's in the harvest field.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Is that the best you can do? How's the boy? Had to give him a rest this round, didn't you?'
speaker: Long John

utterance: Look out for yourself, Lincoln. I'm going to double that bean-pole or heat a pinion.'
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: We caught Little Bill and Ben this round, and Long John, pretty near.
speaker: Owen Stewart

utterance: Did you get him?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Not quite, but I will this time. Get out o' there, Dan.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Well, he got all of us but Luke and that longlegged kangaroo.
speaker: Ben Hutchison

utterance: Looks that way. He'll crow over us all the rest of the harvest, I suppose.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I guess I don't want you round. He's been cheating for the last four rounds. See here.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Now, what I don't understand, is this. How did you expect to do that without being found out?
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Well, I made up my mind at noon I didn't want to work for a man who drives his hands as you do.
speaker: Long John

utterance: But it was your own fault. Your bragging started the whole thing.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Well, let's go to supper. I'm empty as a tin boiler.
speaker: Ben Hutchison

utterance: To-morrow that's where we catch goudy.
speaker: Ben Hutchison

utterance: Oh, I don't know; it may rain.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Anyhow, we've got a good long night to rest in.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Here's your' walking papers. I don't want a hand round me that I can't trust. I don't like your style. Good day.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: You don't want a tent. We will get a place for you at some settler's shanty.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Let 'em feed, boys, while we take a snack.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: I'd like to keep right on all summer, wouldn't you, Rance?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Well, boys, I guess we'll have to go into camp.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Hark!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Leave the saddles on, boys, and put your bridles where you can find them. We may need to rout you out, any time.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Here's the pasture.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Now, Rance, be careful. Put the cattle into the corral every night for a week; after that, if they are quiet, you won't need to. Watch 'em till they fill up, and then go to bed. But if it threatens rain, or if the flies are bad, you'd better bring 'em in. Good-by-take care o' yourselves.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Look out for Saugas.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Go to your meals regular.
speaker: neighbor Jennings

utterance: Well, boys, we're in for it.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: I guess we weigh a hundred and enough.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Milton, you watch the cattle, while Link and I go down and look at that herd of horses.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: All right. Don't be gone long.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: I wonder which is the leader.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: That black mare.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: See her eyes. She's ready to stampede.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Say, boys, we'll have a dandy fight one o' these days. See them cattle?
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Boys, you stay here, and I'll go over an' see that feller.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Hello, where'd you come from?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Cedar County. Where do you live?
speaker: Cecil Johnson

utterance: 'Bout four miles west o' here. What's your name?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Lincoln Stewart. What's yours?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Cecil Johnson. Say, you want to look out for our old bull; he's roamin' round somewhere. He's a terrible fighter.
speaker: Cecil Johnson

utterance: What if he is? If he comes round our herd, old Spot'll 'tend to him.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Mebbe he will and mebbe he won't. Old Brin killed a steer last Sunday. You want to keep on your horse when he comes round.
speaker: Cecil Johnson

utterance: We ain't afraid, but you want 'o head your herd south, o' there'll be war.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I guess our cattle can take care o' their selves.
speaker: Cecil Johnson

utterance: Let 'em come; we're here first.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Let's kinder aige 'em along toward each other, and have it over an' done with.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Oh, gosh, no! If we did, an' some of 'em got killed, we'd catch lightnin'; but if they come together themselves, we're not to blame.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: That's the brindle bull. He's comin' this way, too.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Well, let him come. Old Spot will meet him.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Old Brin is still on deck; don't you forget it.
speaker: Cecil Johnson

utterance: He's killed him. Old Spot's killed him.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Not much he hasn't. A bull never gives up. He's just beginning to get mad.
speaker: Cecil Johnson

utterance: I hope it won't rain to-night.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I'm a little nervous myself.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: It would be just our luck to have a three-days soaker.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: I'm going home to get a square meal.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: He had heart disease, anyway. He wouldn't have died if he had been a well man.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Rattlesnake! Rattlesnake!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Shut up! Keep still. Crying only makes it worse. Link, give me a strap, quick.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Set it up tight. It's the only chance.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Say, you remember the story about putting the fellow in the mud?
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Well, you go for help. I'm going to put the boy into that puddle and hold him there. Here, you fellers. Come here.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Git, Link. Ride like split!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: What you 'fraid of? Grab a hold here. The snake is gone. We've got to get this boy into that puddle. One of you hold my horse. You take hold here.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Lie still, now. I won't drown you. You'll die if you don't do as I say. Dig, dig!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Sink him down. There, don't that feel good? That cool mud will draw the poison out. One o' you go cut a big hazel bush. I'm going to keep the 'turnkey' on him.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: It won't do no good if it don't hurt.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: He was in the path. I stepped on him.
speaker: Freddie

utterance: Hello! Hae baen bit by snake?
speaker: Anderson

utterance: That's what. Come here and take hold of this turnkey. I'm just about used up.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Ae got al-co-hol. Yimmy, haer, yo' take good swig.
speaker: Anderson

utterance: I can't. I can't!
speaker: Freddie

utterance: Batter yo' try. Hae baen gude.
speaker: Anderson

utterance: Why didn't you bring some water to mix with it? Go get some quick. He can't drink that stuff.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Here comes somebody.
speaker: boys

utterance: He's all right. Don't worry.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: You hear. He's alive. Be quiet now.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: What's he in the mud for? Take him out.
speaker: Freddie's father

utterance: That's all right. Leave him alone.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Good idea.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Do you know me, Freddie?
speaker: Mrs. Pease

utterance: Well — bote tem to eat; ae tank ae go home. Batter yo go home too, Link.
speaker: Anderson

utterance: As soon as we kill the snake.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: They didn't thank you for putting that boy in the mud, did they? It got his clothes dirty.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Are you the chap that put Fred into the mud?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Yes, I am. What y' goin' to do about it?
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: You needn't get huffy. I just came over to say that my sister, Mrs. Pease, wants to see you. The doctor says
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
Well, you go back and let me alone. The next time your fool boy gets bit, he can go hang- I did the best I could, and I've been devilled about it ever since, and I'm sick of it.
Think I'm a doctor out here herdin' cattle for my health?
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance:
I didn't mean to devil him. The doctor said the boy done the best thing that could a' been done.
Mrs. Pease did send me over here to get the boy.
speaker: the stranger

utterance:
Well, you let him alone.
don't want a woman slobbering over him. He did the best he knew how, and that's all anybody can do.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: We mustn't wind our nags. Let's tie up.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: If you want to scoop in that saddle, Owen, you keep well.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: No hired man shall chaw my hair off again, and don't you forget it.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Lincoln, go get the team; I've entered you for the pulling match.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Oh, I can't do that before all those people.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance:
Yes, you can.
Go hitch up.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Keep quiet, everybody. All ready, my boy.
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Steady now, Jule. Chk-chk, Dan, steady now.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Get down there, Jule.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Bully boy!
speaker: the crowd

utterance: All right, take 'em off for a minute. Anderson, it's your turn again.
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Take 'em off; they're no good.
speaker: the audience

utterance: Dexter, boy!
speaker: Lime Gilman

utterance: Ho! that'll do, boys.
speaker: Lime Gilman

utterance: Try again, Link.
speaker: Lime Gilman

utterance: It's yours.
speaker: the crowd

utterance: Oh, no it isn't. I know this boy and his team!
speaker: Lime Gilman

utterance: They're up too high upon legs.
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Pile on two more stones.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Good for you, sonny !
speaker: some one

utterance: Stiddy, Dan. Take hold of it; w-o-oo-p, stiddy!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Now, Jule!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Ho!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Give it up. Take off a stone.
speaker: a friendly voice

utterance: Not much.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Fule!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: That's enough. Unhitch.
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Good boy, Link.
speaker: Lime Gilman

utterance: Easy now, Dexter. Easy, Dave. Now then, boys, all together. Get down, hoy!
speaker: Lime Gilman

utterance: That's what ye might call pullin'.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Call it a draw, Judge.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I'm willing.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: We'll divide the honors, Lime.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: I knew old Jule would lift it.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: But Lime's team scared me. I knew they could pull. I've seen 'em dig down on a load while Lime lit his pipe.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Get ready for 'the Boys' Contest.'
speaker: the crier

utterance: That's you, Owen.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Don't touch her with the whip.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Look out for the crowd at the home-stretch.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: HOLD HIM UP A LITTLE!
speaker: Sandy's father

utterance: Hold him up a little.
speaker: Sandy's sister

utterance: LET HIM OUT A GRAIN!
speaker: Sandy's father

utterance: Let him out a grain.
speaker: Sandy's sister

utterance: SET UP A LITTLE.
speaker: Sandy's father

utterance: Set up a little.
speaker: Sandy's sister

utterance: Now, boys, we want you to ride up and down past us, for a few turns. Don't crowd each other, and don't hurry, and do your prettiest.
speaker: the Judge

utterance: When you turn again, go round the track-and don't race.
speaker: the Judge

utterance: LET HIM GO, SON!
speaker: Sandy's father

utterance: Let him go, son.
speaker: Sandy's sister

utterance: Where's Owen?
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Wait a minute. He'll show up soon.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance:
Oh, catch him, will you? Let's see you do it.
Now where are your fancy riders?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: He's won it! He's won it sure!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Aw, no.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Stewart!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Sandy!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: The other one the bare-headed boy!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: This is favoritism. Anybody can ride those trained town ponies. The decision lies between MacElroy's son and Owen Stewart. Put your slick little gentlemen on those two horses, and see how they will go through.
speaker: neighbor Jennings

utterance: This ain't no fair shake. I wouldn't a minded your givin' it to the feller on the bay mare, but them little rockin'-horse ponies-why, a suckin' goose can ride one of them.
speaker: MacElroy

utterance: Now this is my opinion.
speaker: one of the Judges

utterance: I voted for the first prize to go to Stewart, the second prize to MacElroy, and let 'em change horses and see what they can do.
speaker: one of the Judges

utterance: That's fair. That's right.
speaker: several bystanders

utterance:
But, I was out-voted.
Mine is a minority report, and can't stand.
speaker: the third Judge

utterance:
Mr. Middleton, having decided to vote with Mr.
Scott, we have to announce that the first prize will go as before to Master Simpson, the second to Master Stewart, and the third to Master MacElroy, and this is final.
speaker: the Chairman

utterance: Clear the track for the Free-for-all running race best two in three.
speaker: the Judge

utterance: I say, your horse can run five or six a minute, can't she?
speaker: Sandy

utterance:
I was scared one while, when I saw your old Sorrel a-comin'. I'm dry. Le's go have some lemonade.
Link, hold our horses.
speaker: Owen Stewart

utterance: Get out your horses for the four-year-old sweepstakes.
speaker: the Marshal

utterance: Bring out your horses.
speaker: the Marshal

utterance: Oh, let's see that.
speaker: Owen Stewart

utterance: Let's climb the fence.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Is Owen Stewart here?
speaker: the Marshal

utterance: Yes!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Here he is.
speaker: a dozen voices

utterance: You're wanted at the Judges' Stand. Come along.
speaker: the Marshal

utterance: Go ahead.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance:
Come on, I'll go with you.
It's something more about the prize.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Here's your boy.
speaker: the Marshal

utterance: Come up here, son.
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Will this boy answer?
speaker: a tall and much excited man

utterance: Now, my boy, you are to ride this man's horse in the race, because his own boy is too light. Do you think you can handle a race-horse?
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Yes, sir.
speaker: Owen Stewart

utterance: All right, sir, if his father is willing, I can mount your horse.
speaker: the Judge

utterance: You needn't be afraid. When once she's off, 'Gyp' is perfectly safe.
speaker: Mr. Mills

utterance: I don't think he's afraid. You tell him what you want him to do, and he'll do it.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: Now there are two horses. The bald-faced sorrel don't cut any figger- -but the black, the Ansgor horse, is sure to get away first for Gypsy is freaky at the wire. You will couple of lengths behind, but don't worry don't force the mare till you come around about that the last turn.
speaker: Mr. Mills

utterance: Let down my stirrups. I can't ride with my knees up there.
speaker: Owen Stewart

utterance: Don't worry, mother; he's all right.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: No, you don't!
speaker: a town boy

utterance: He won't do that again, Don't you worry.
speaker: Owen Stewart

utterance: Don't let him jockey you. Pass him on the back stretch, when he ain't lookin'.
speaker: jockey on the sorrel

utterance: I'll give you ten dollars to ride Gypsy at Independence
speaker: Mr. Mills

utterance: All right
speaker: Owen Stewart

utterance: Down, Growler
speaker: Sam Hutchison

utterance: Put 'em up, boy-steady, now!
speaker: Sam Hutchison

utterance: Go on, boy!
speaker: Sam Hutchison

utterance: I'd as soon eat prairie hay.
speaker: Sam Hutchison

utterance: I kill no more hens and cats.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: When I go hunting now, it's got to be wolves or foxes or bears and buffaloes; hear me.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Let's make a compact.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Four years from now we meet on the plains.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Done!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Be seated! Take your seats again!
speaker: the teacher

utterance: It's the Grove School.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Give attention to books now!
speaker: the teacher

utterance: I'd like to soak Bill Hatfield with a hard snowball.
speaker: Ben Hutchison

utterance: Go away. I don't want any truck with you.
speaker: Sun Prairie boys

utterance: We'll try that again.
speaker: Metellus Soper

utterance: Guess I'll stop while my credit's good.
speaker: Ben Hutchison

utterance: You try that again, or fight.
speaker: Metellus Soper

utterance: Oh, all right—but play fair.
speaker: Ben Hutchison

utterance: I want to take a whirl with you.
speaker: Metellus Soper

utterance: Oh, take some one of your size,
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I'll take you, rough and tumble.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Any way 't all.
speaker: Metellus Soper

utterance: Put him on his back!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Blame your slippery hide, I'll smash ye!
speaker: Metellus Soper

utterance: Go fair now.
speaker: the boys

utterance: Aw! Go ahead, Mett, don't lay there and tire him all out. That ain't rastlin'.
speaker: The crowd

utterance: Why Mett, what are you doing there under this little boy?
speaker: Jasper

utterance: Don't bother him; he's busy!
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Call it a draw, boys
speaker: Jasper

utterance: Let him up, Mett. Call it a draw.
speaker: the rest

utterance: This ain't ended.
speaker: Metellus Soper

utterance: I'm ready, any time.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: But I want to tell you right now you've got to rastle fair, or I'll let the daylight into you. I won't be mauled around by a big bully like you.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Lay aside books. We will now spell down. James Poindexter and Henry Coonrod may choose sides.
speaker: the teacher

utterance: I can't wrestle for shucks, but I can spell with any of you.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: School is dismissed.
speaker: the teacher

utterance: Hello, Milt.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Hello, Carrie.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Hello, Bettie.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: I'm going to go to the Seminary myself when I'm eighteen.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I'm going to start in next year.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Oh, you're coddin'.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance:
Not much I ain't; what's the use going on here?
Our teacher can't carry us any further. I'm going to go to college and I'm going to do something else besides farm. You can't do anything worth while without an education - I've found that out.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Will your father let you go?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance:
He'll growl at the expense, but I can fix that.
The boys tell me they can live for about two dollars a week down there by "baching it," and we could cut that down if we had to. It's settled so far as I'm concerned. This is my last winter in Sun Prairie, now you hear me!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: That's Milt!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Hello, Link.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Hello, Milt.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Ain't you up awful early for a Seminary chap?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Oh, I guess I hain't lost all my staminy with one term o' school.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Had breakfast?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Yup.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Well, I ain't, so you put Mark in the barn an' wait a week or two, while I eat.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Ginger, but he's a jim dandy. I didn't think you'd ride him to-da Rance better look out.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I'm ridi to win, this time.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Steady, Mark, old boy,— steady!
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: What horse you goin' to ride?
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance:
Well, I don't know. Rob, I guess.
Cassius is too heavy for such work, don't you think?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: No. Cassius is the best. You see the main thing to-day is, to have a horse that can hold out.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: What you got to shoot with?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: A Colt's revolver that I borrowed from Lime Gilman.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Well, I guess I'll have to confine my death-dealing weapons to my vocal organs.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Why so?
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: That is, if I ride Cassius. Look at the eyes of him.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Hoh!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Look out, there.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Wo-up, old man-stiddy now!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Hello, cap! We'd about give you up.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Want some coffee, Rance?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: No, climb onto your horses.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: What you got to shoot with?
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: All right. Now we must be off. Keep behind me and don't race and don't make too much noise. We strike for the big popple grove. Already-into line. March.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance:
Now, then, Lincoln, you take Milt and Cy, and strike into that patch of hazel bush to the right, and remember, if you start a wolf, don't try to run him down, unless you're close onto him. He'll run in a circle and while you're after him, fire a shot to let us know, and we'll cut across lots. When we strike his trail you pull right off, and cut across behind us.
If he turns to the right or left, let us know.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Halt! Hold on there!
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance:
Now, what kind of a way of doing business is that?
How many wolves are you going to kill by winding every horse in the crowd the first jump? You'll kill more horses than wolves. Now listen to me: We don't want more than three horses after the wolf at the same time. The others must cut him off. Don't be in wait and see where he's heading.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Milt and Lincoln were all right. They started the game. But the rest of you were all wrong. Now, the wolf is in that big tow-head there. Cy, you go to the right, and, Milt, you go to the left, and I'll take the centre, and we'll see if we can go at this manfashion.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: He's going back!
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: See that horse run!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: The ears are yours, Link. That crazy old fool of yours did the business.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Now we'll strike for Rattlesnake Grove, and go through every patch of hazel brush on the way.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Fall in, everybody.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Oh, for a rifle!
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Ride onto him with y'r pistol.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance:
No, wait; there's Cy Hurd, he's got a rifle. Why, he don't see him! the donkey!
Hay! there he is!
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Now, Mark!
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: What's the matter? Hurt?
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance:
I guess my leg's banged up a little; it's numb.
Where's my horse?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: We'll take care of the horse.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Somebody get that cutter, quick. Catch the horse and take his blanket off. We'll need it to wrap Link up in. He's hurt pretty bad, I reckon.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: I guess I ain't hurt very much. The snow kind o' broke the force of the fall.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I'm all right.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: It don't hurt — much now.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: It serves you right
speaker: Bettie

utterance: to go chasing those poor little wolves all over the prairie. How do you s'pose you'd feel to have a whole raft of Indians ridin' down on top of you, and shootin' pistols and yellin'?
speaker: Bettie

utterance: Wouldn't feel much worse'n I do now.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Milt, you ride - ahead and tell mother I'm all right.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance:
Where is Lincoln ?
Is he hurt?
speaker: Mrs. Stewart

utterance:
Not very bad, I guess. Cassius fell with him.
He's comin' in the cutter.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: Tell Duncan, quick. He's in the barn. I've expected that colt would do something.
speaker: Mrs. Stewart

utterance: Saddle Rob, and get a doctor as quick as the Lord'll let you.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: I'll be with you next year, boys, or bust a tug.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Things'll come around by and by.
speaker: Mrs. Stewart

utterance: Times are slack just now, and I think I'll run out and see you.
speaker: Robert Stewart

utterance: My theory is, if you can't do the best thing in life, do the next best.
speaker: Robert Stewart

utterance:
See here, Duncan, you've a discontented, ambitious boy on your hands. He don't like farming, he's just at the age when a schooling is necessary. Why not let him come home with me?
He can go to school in season, and help me at my trade during vacation. Mary and me have no children at all, and you have three. Now see here! You couldn't hold this boy more than five years more, anyway, and I can do for him at small expense what you don't feel able to do at all.
speaker: Robert Stewart

utterance: I will not wear out my life milking COWS. I hate it. Part of farming I like, but I am going to have an education in something else beside hauling
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Well, Lincoln, we've decided to let you go home with Robert as soon as you're able.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance: I won't go, mother, if you don't want me to.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Come in, Rob; we've told him.
speaker: Duncan Stewart

utterance:
Well! Well!
What's all this crying about?
We're not going to put him in jail. Come now, if you're going to take it so hard as all that, I back out.
speaker: Robert Stewart

utterance: Now take care of yourself, boy, and be ready to come on in April.
speaker: Robert Stewart

utterance: Criminy! that's a deadner on us. I thought sure you'd be with us next spring. Well, it's a good chance for you. You can go to college now, sure.
speaker: Milton Jennings

utterance: That's what I will.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: what of Ladrone” - do you ask?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Oh! friend, I am sad at the name.
speaker: narrator

utterance: The task You require is a hard one at best.
speaker: narrator

utterance:
Huzzah, my wild beauty! Your best; Will you teach my Ladrone a new pace?
Will you break his proud heart in a shame By spurning the dust in his face?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Aha, she is lost! she does not respond.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Like a hound from the leash, my Ladrone Swoops ahead— We're alone on the plain!
speaker: narrator

utterance:
What! sold your preserver, your mate, he who Through wind and wild snow and deep night Brought you safe to a shelter at last?
Did you, when the danger had end, Forget your dumb hero—your friend?
speaker: friend

utterance: Forget! no, nor can I.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Why, man, It's little you know of such love As I felt for him! You think that you feel The same deep regard for your span, Blanketed, shining, and clipped to the heel.
speaker: narrator

utterance:
No, I do not forget; but who Is the master of fortune and fate?
Who does as he wishes and not as he must?
When I sold my preserver, my mate, My faithfullest friend-man, I wept.
Yes, I own it! His beautiful eyes Seemed to ask what it meant.
And he kept them fixed on me in startled surprise, As another hand led him away.
And the last that I heard of my roan, Was the sound of his shrill, pleading neigh!
speaker: narrator

utterance: They are not much like the cattle of the range.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: It seems a long time ago, don't it?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Seems longer to me than to you. I've spent all my vacations at home.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance:
I wish I had taken Madison instead of Ripon, but it was a ground-hog case.
How do you like teaching?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance:
First rate.
It gives me time to read, and pays as well as anything I can get into.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Do you go back to Cedarville next year?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: No; since I wrote you I've got a better thing. I go as assistant principal of the Winnesheik High School.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: That's good. I hate teaching. It looks now as though I'd have to be a seedy lawyer, as father says; They're going to run father for county treasurer, and that will put me in line for promotion. That's Old Man Bacon's place.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: He never would fix up like that.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Oh, Lime Gilman did that. He's moved in on the old man. Old Bill fell and hurt his back, and can't do anything but just hobble around.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance:
That's hard lines for him; what a worker he was!
I'd like to see Marietta. Is she as handsome as ever ?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Pretty near. Lime takes care of her. They have the best furniture in the township. Lime is the same easy-going chap that he used to be.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance:
Yes, when the wheat crops began to fail, all these changes came with a rush. The country went from grain to cows in a couple of years. I used to notice a difference every year when I came home.
Less wheat, more cows.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: That's Hutchison's place; looks very much the same. Ben at home?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: No, Ben went to Dakota. There's a big exodus just now for the Green River valley. Hum Bunn — you remember Hum and our fight?-well, he's out there, and Doudney and the Dixons and Peases. Milt thought of going, but he married Eileen Deering and got a county office, and that settled him.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance:
I heard about that. Milt will take care of himself.
He'll joke his way into Congress sure as eggs raise chickens, as Old Man Doudney used to say.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I'd like to see a strip of wild meadow. Is it all gone?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance:
I don't know of any - not a rod. There be may some off to the north where we used to hunt wolves.
We might go and see.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Let's do it. It would do me a heap o' good to see some of the good old weeds and grasses. I suppose a fellow'd have to go clear to the Missouri River to see a vacant quarter-section.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance:
I don't believe there is any vacant land in the state there may be some in the extreme northwest, over beyond the Coon Fork. Last year brought a tremendous rush of settlement, and I hear everything was taken clear through to the line. Norwegians came in swarms.
Well, there's the Knapp place —not so much changed; trees have grown up, that's all.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: I used to stand very much in awe of your sisters. Is Agnes at home?
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Yes. Bess is in Dakota. She married Ed Bartle.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: I remember your writing to me about it. I used to think they were the handsomest women in the world.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Owen, I hear, is a great sprinter.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance:
Owen is all right. He's 'short stop' in the college nine, and has held first place on the two hundred and twenty yards course for three years.
He's actually had his name in the Chicago papers and is quite set up about it. He's a good all-round athlete, but not a bit ambitious otherwise.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: I'd like to see the boy. He was a queer little josy when we all rode horses on the prairie. By the way, do you ride?
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Haven't been on a horse since I left here.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: Neither have I. It might be a curious job to dig up some saddles and ride out to-morrow.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Good! I'm with you.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: We had almost given up expecting you.
speaker: Agnes

utterance: From the looks of these saddles the rats thought we were done with them. I guess they're right. It would lame us, anyhow, to ride these big horses; if we had Ladrone and Ivanhoe, the case would be different. I guess we'll have to drive.
speaker: Rance Knapp

utterance: Here it is! Here they are the buffalo berries, the rose bushes, the rattlesnake weed, wild barley, plums all of it.
speaker: Lincoln Stewart

utterance: We'll meet them yet, they are not lost forever ; They lie somewhere, those splendid prairie lands, Far in the West, untouched of plough and harrow Unmarked by man's all-desolating hands.
speaker: Rance Knapp
